1:57, let's think about what is being said here. To say '(biological) men have larger hippocami" means that an average, men have larger hippocampi on average relative to their brain size. This is true. And when they say similar things about (biological) woman's brains this is also a statement of differences in average among that group.

Now we test 100 trans women's brains and compare them to the average of biological males brains. We find that trans women do in fact have averages lower than bio males, closer to 'real' females. This is ALL fine!

BUT to say that that average brain mass difference is evidence that those people ARE in fact, 'actually female' is hard to define. Are we saying a man is defined by how closely the relative size of structures in his brian match up to the average male?

What if a cis Male's brain scan perfectly matches up with that of the female brain averages!! Is he actually trans and unaware if it? Or is he a man with smaller relative brain structures? The issue here is that relative sizes/ densities of components of the brain is NOWHERE NEAR ENOUGH INFO to put a scientific finger on what gender actually IS.

If you ask me, I don't think gender is anything other than this:certains behaviors we associate with 'maleness' and 'femaleness'. These associations are not only arbitrary but fluid. They change from culture to culture, one decade to the next.

A transistor is a semiconductor device used to amplify or switch electronic signals and electrical power. Transistors are one of the basic building blocks of modern electronics. It is composed of semiconductor material usually with at least three terminals for connection to an external circuit. A voltage or current applied to one pair of the transistor's terminals controls the current through another pair of terminals. Because the controlled (output) power can be higher than the controlling (input) power, a transistor can amplify a signal. Today, some transistors are packaged individually, but many more are found embedded in integrated circuits.

I hope this sounds respectful, but I’m concerned about this video. It’s important to note that science does not validate or invalidate anything. This video seems to place a lot of emphasis on the physical appearance of the brain studies, ie the hardware, rather than the software. It’s important to note that these studies are inconclusive but that doesn’t negate that transgender individuals exist, they obviously do. However, there is a psychological component as well. Let’s say there is a tendency for a little less or more gray matter in specific areas of the brain of a transgender person, that doesn’t mean that all people with that characteristic will be transgender. Science likely will not find that specifically either. Are you going to deny someone’s truth if that person does not have the right amount of gray matter?  It’s important we not lie about the science and it’s importance. I’m finding a lot of badly interpreted and reported information on this that seems motivated to misinform in order to validate. It’s unfortunate because validation doesn’t need science.

I’ve no issue with people who feel alienated in their bodies, my heart goes out to them.

My problem stems from this seemingly growing tendency to say that I can no longer admire masculinity and femininity due to the risk of ostracizing those who identify with neither. That to look upon a woman or man in admiration of their respective traits is to be, by default, intolerant or “toxic” because it’s an acknowledgment and appreciation of the binary. That we must believe that men and women are wholly interchangeable and that our biological determinants hold absolutely no bearing on aspects such as gender identity, expressions, and roles. I do not believe that, and science is exemplifying such distinctions and is challenging the politically correct, idealistic narrative that gender is exclusively a societal and cultural construct by demonstrating that male and female brains and the manner in which they function, are in fact, different. And found within those differences exist certain behavioral and emotional proclivities that tend to manifest in the aforementioned aspects such as identity, expressions and roles. Not without exception obviously, but I believe it holds valid as a general truism. And with the transgender community comprising a population of what....0.6% of the entire U.S population (let’s grant double that to 1+%)? My sympathies extend to them, deeply so, but I’m sorry, I’m not willing to completely redefine what has traditionally defined the sexes and their place in society up to this point.

I am not ashamed, nor will I apologize for, holding appreciation for the beauty of the binary and the distinctions that delineate it.....that is not synonymous with being bigoted towards those who don’t identify with either side of the aisle.

Additionally, identifying anatomy quickly makes dating and healthcare more streamlined.

​ @Robert Platt "Gender is a way for us to categorize ourselves and others by action and reaction. This is driven by psychology which is derived from both biology and experience - thus the near infinite diversity."
Also known as "personality". You don't have to call it a different gender every time someone differs in how they think, feel, and behave.

"I know I have a woman's mind because no matter how anyone has taught, explained, hypnotically suggested or commanded, I cannot think differently than I do."

So certain things about your personality cannot be changed. Doesn't mean you have "a woman's mind". Again, how do you even know what having a woman's mind vs. having a man's mind feels like? For all you know, they feel the exact same, and the only way men and women ever feel differently is through biological causes.

"My thoughts and emotions cause distress because they don't fit this body"

Again, gender roles. You are not obligated to think or feel particular ways just because you're a man. Tons of men out there "think like a woman" or "have emotions like a woman" (and I put these in quotations because I still find the idea sexist to begin with) and yet "identify" as men because they understand that the distinction is the realm of biology.

"A few examples include: I have always wanted soft, smooth curves and to be a mother."

So you are unhappy with your gender. That's unfortunate. But it doesn't change or affect reality, and I think the sooner you acknowledge that the better your changes of accepting that gender so you can move on to asking the better questions:
Why do you want to be a mother? What do mothers do? How do they contribute to their children/society? Isn't it entirely possible to fulfill those needs (which are indeed important) as a man?

"I'm highly empathetic toward others. I don't understand the intrigue with sports or porn."

Same here x3. But I know that doesn't make me any less of a man. Also, plenty of women (who "identify" as women) lack empathy, love sports and watch pornography.

"I am isolated from most men because I am so different psychologically and isolated from most women because I am so different biologically. Etc."

Story of my life! And I'm not just saying that. My friend, I don't even know how to change a tire. I know pretty much none of the things men are expected to know, and the only stereotypically "guy thing" I'm into are video games.

"To make my thoughts and emotions fit my body requires barbaric "brainwashing" techniques that are only marginally successful and produce a multitude of equally nasty side effects like PTSD. "

You need to let go of this notion of thoughts and feelings "fitting bodies", and so does anyone who gives you shit over not being "enough of a man". Your body is male, and I presume that you're an adult, therefore you're a man. Your thoughts and feelings only make you you. The odds were that biology would greatly influence your personality, but you beat those odds and broke free from gender norms. If anything, this is something to celebrate, not run or hide from.

"Lastly, identifying as something measurable (age, race, social status) is provably true or false."

Exactly. And being a man or woman is measurable through biology. If you have zero biological evidence that you're a woman, yet you want people to treat you as one, there's nothing stopping me from applying this principle to pressure others into treating me as a different age, race, and financial status.

"In any case the most obvious difference between these identifications and gender dysphoria is that they don't cause distress."

To your knowledge. But I'm quite sure that if you give it time, people will be popping up with their stories of how "always knowing they were black" (when they're white) and having to be misraced, etc. caused them great pain and suffering. Because again, what's stopping them? Even if you say they're just faking it all, how can you prove that? You can't.

"If someone does suffer then it's up to the individual to do something about it - just as it is with gender dysphoria."

Yeah, like coming to grips with the objective truth, and then asking why they identify as something they're not.

"And if there's sufficient determination, a poor person may earn their way to a higher social class,"

No no no. Don't be a bigot. These people are already rich, and you have to treat them as such. And that will have all sorts of interesting applications when they happen to stroll into the nearest bank, wouldn't you say?

"an old person may act and think as a younger person."

Right, like a 40-year old man who identifies as a 15-year old boy can date your daughter. What could you say against that? You don't want to be a hateful bigot, keep that in mind.

"Society accepts and encourages these people. Ever see an old man on a skateboard doing tricks and having a blast?"

That's just it, though. He can do these things because he's able to, not because he identifies as someone younger. Similarly, you can fulfill the same needs as any mother, without being a woman. And that would be OK but competing in sports against biological women is not. Just as the old man can ride skateboards in the park, but cannot date a teenage girl.

"But few will correct them if they say they feel young or rich or whatever. Yet many will correct me for saying I feel like a woman."

Partly because (so far), there isn't a movement of old people claiming they are in fact young or poor people claiming they are in fact rich. So the guard can be lowered there. Also partly because "feeling young" refers to differences in young people that most wouldn't dispute. It's almost inevitable that a young person (who is healthy) will have more energy. It is not almost inevitable that a woman will think, feel, and behave the way you are.

"So if I require a female-shaped body to function (regardless of my DNA), is it correct to deny it?"

You don't require that at all. The issue is in the mind, so that's where you should fix it.

"Living authentic is more important."

Indeed. So if you are a man who thinks, feels, and behaves in a very different way from most men, that's what you say. That's what you know about yourself, and so that's what you should tell others.

This somewhat distorts the science, when it categorically states that the brains of transgender people are closer to the opposite gender from their body gender; actually, the scientific literature is more mixed than this portrays. For example, it identifies 5 statistical differences, all being spectrums rather than binary distinctions. Think of 5 slider knobs. A biological cis male will likely have all of those knobs (eg: volume of right frontal lobe) more or less on one side, and a biological cis female will likely have all of those knobs generally on the other side - altho not at the far ends of the spectrum (knob at end of its travel). Transgender folk may have one or more of these knobs more towards the middle or towards the other side; but they may at the same time have another knob still more towards their body gender. So in regard to one knob (one brain metric), they might be more like the opposite gender, but in regard to another they might be more like their body gender. To suggest that every trans person has all of these metrics ("knobs" in the analogy) strongly matching the cis gender brains of the opposite gender would not be an accurate reading of the science. These metrics/knobs do not always move in lockstep with each other.

There are clusters tho. Some researchers find that from scans they can identify brains as cismale, cisfemale, ftm, or mtf - four categories, not two.

It would be more accurate to say that people whose brains differ substantially in any or all of these metrics from their body gender often (but not always) suffer gender dysphoria (or some milder condition similar to GD but without significant distress) and thus come to identify as trans. This is a real thing, just like body intersex, and it deserves compassionate and humane responses from individuals and society, but it's more complex than this video portrays it; it doesn't come down to toggling a binary brain type between two alternatives.

The simple characterization "more like the brain of the opposite body gender" is not a fair summary, unless you add "in some ways".

This comment is about honest, non-political scientific accuracy. In no way does the science support hostility or oppression; everybody must be well treated, regardless of such brain metrics. We can't empathize this enough - no hate or bigotry is OK. But this positive attitude is and must be compatible with honest science and the objective universe.

Dig deeper and you find that the science is nowhere near as definitive as this video makes it seem. We cannot confidently make the claims they are making. Plus, interpretation of the findings they cite is still widely debated. They are also cherry-picking. Lots of contrary findings are out there as well.

Bottom line, this stuff is in its infancy; they are getting way ahead of themselves.

That said, it is nice to see that research is starting to produce some initial insights and showing that there is likely at least some biological component to what trans people experience. And whatever we find, it is especially nice to see attitudes in general are becoming more accepting. Obviously we have a long way to go but I am happy to see how far we have come.

Fairly decent video and pleasantly surprised at the nonbiased approach. The only two problems I had with the video was when they were talking about the brain and the suicide rate. We don’t know nearly enough about the brain to be able to say what is exactly linking the shape of the brain and it’s connection to gender dysphoria. The suicide rate isn’t just high, it’s 10x national average; 40%. No other group in history has ever come close to that high of a suicide rate; not the African Americans before 1960 that were treated as lesser human beings, nor homosexuals during the 1970-1980 HIV scare when society thought the frightening disease was attributed to them. While there are horrible people out there, 40% is far too high to attribute to social intolerance; more likely linking with severe depression caused by uncontrollable chemical imbalance of neurotransmitters (ex: dopamine). There are no studies to show that tolerance and surgery will lower depression and the suicide rate to a “normal” rate. As someone who has been medically treated for severe depression, I feel nothing but sympathy and wish kindness for these people going through such a tough life. Although I sympathize, I cannot accept that tolerance is the only hope. If we accept that tolerance is the only option, we less likely to find any other option. If in the future I have a kid with gender dysphoria, I don’t want to be basically flipping a coin to see whether or not he will commit suicide.

To be honest the notion of being transgender, and feeling the need to transition, baffles me. I don't care if people are transgender, I literally just don't get it. I explain why below. If someone could explain it to me, that would be great!

Why does it actually matter whether your body matches the gender in your head? I'm a straight guy, but I don't think I'd care if my body suddenly changed to a woman's. Actually, I'd kinda like to have a beautiful woman's body :) but its not really important. I don't really wrap up my identity in being a 'man' or 'guy' that strongly - I'm just a person who happens to exist in a male body. Both kinds of bodies can function, experience sexual pleasure, and reproduce.

Sure, there are typically 'masculine' things like playing rugby, and typically 'feminine' things like dolls and wearing dresses. But those are social constructs - boys could play with dolls and girls could play rugby. Yes, men and women dress differently, but clothes are really just a tool and a social norm. Yes, there are typical gender roles with relationships, but they're not gospel - some guys like myself like having a strong woman to look after them.

So basically, if we stop siloing things as masculine or feminine, is there anything actually left? Do we really need to base our identity as 'man' or 'woman' rather than just 'person'? And if we don't, could we say that transgenderism is a mental illness?

Yes, people should be allowed to transition if they want, but if it is possible just to accept your body as is, that seems way easier to me.

Am I missing something, here? I'm not trying to be dismissive - I'm just trying to understand it. Thanks in advance for any enlightenment!

I've been working on artificial neural networks and I've learned a few things that most people in the comments section don't seem to get.

Gender dysphoria is a wiring disorder. You can't treat a wiring disorder with any kind of drug or hormone.

Once the wiring is set it can't change unless the connections being removed have very low weights attached to them.
This is something the brain can do on its own when necessary.

Removing connections with small weights won't cause immediate problems but it can cause the network to have trouble learning new things in the future.

Anything else that alters the wiring would be brain damage. The wiring is set at birth and trying to change it to "cure Autism" or "eliminate geder dysphoria" would simply be playing God.

The way you treat wiring disorders is by teaching them how to deal with it (which is how Autism treatment works), or changing the rest of the body to fit the brain (I.e. Hormone replacement therapy)

Sources:
* machine learning course by Andrew Ng
* https://www.nytimes.com/2014/08/22/health/brains-of-autistic-children-have-too-many-synapses-study-suggests.html
* my own ability to reason about neural nets

It's important to note that the brain is plastic. The fact that trans people's brains are more physically in line with cis people with their same gender identity is not necessarily an indication that their "transness" is a result of that brain structure. It seems just as likely that those neurological differences are a direct result of socialization, self-perception, and behavioral habits, meaning that trans people of a certain gender think in similar ways to cis people of that same gender, leading to physical changes in the brain.

Also, a lot of those physical differences between genders are fairly minute: it's not like the hypothalamus of the average man is twice as big as that of the average woman.

Most of the above journal articles are on sexual determination and gonadal development. Several of the last links are simply news articles with little to no scientific references. It also simplifies or completely ignores the cultural component of culture and tries to claim brain structural differences (of which is there is only one consistently found in an area of the brain with an unknown function) are explanation for behavior. Not looking to debate here, nor do I advocate hatred of trans people. In fact I believe that with such high suicide rates that they should be treated with more love.
However I urge a consideration of this yourselves. Are the neurological abnormalities in trans people to be embraced? Now wait here for a second, if there were neurological abnormalities in a person who had a learning disability, would the best way to handle that disability be to embrace their condition, or strive against it. I fear that modifying the body is not so much of a solution, as you essentially are not accepting how beautiful and amazing your human body is as. I care about transgender people as I would about any other member of the human race, and I know that the majority likely have these abnormalities. So the question would then be “is it kindness love and empathy to help someone to appear the way that they feel, or accept the way that they are, and in that way learn to love themselves for who they are?” I am also concerned that trans people through surgery are attempting to kill off their previous self, changing everything that they have known since birth, and every person will treat them differently, not because they are trans, but because they appear female or male.
I think that it is natural for any family to treat that person differently based upon their apparent gender (no I’m not advocating hatred here, hear me out). For example, if you have a group of men let’s say ten or so, the relationship between those men change drastically when one woman is placed in the group. Families are the origins of where we learn as humans where to treat men and women. From our fathers we learn how to treat men, and how to be chivalrous towards women. From our mothers we learn how to love our future children, how women interact with one another, and the qualities of a good wife.
This is not the result of a failed society, but rather the result of natural interactions and hormones changing when a man is introduced to a woman. The truth is that you treat different things differently, as you would not eat a shoe and wear apples. Men are naturally designed to be protectors for women and their children, and this is the reason for why men generally have a stronger body structure, why their brains are different. Let’s stay in reality here, between a 5’8” man and a 5’8” woman, who would be more inclined to break up a fight or use force to protect another?
Ending point, we must accept who nature has designed us to be, as fighting nature does not conform with the minds which we are born with. As a general rule for happiness in ones life, we should look to perfect our minds and our hearts, our reason and our love, and those things which contradict reason and love do not help ourselves to become better, and they do not lead to happiness.

Hey just throwing this out there, most of those studies 'proving' differences in male and female brains are actually widely debated in terms of accuracy due to having very small sample sizes, occasionally questionable methodology, and the fact that similar studies that happen to find fewer or no differences between male and female brains rarely present that factor in the news/publications. If anyone's interested in this topic, I recommend the book "Delusions of Gender" by Cordelia Fine (I know how the title sounds but it's not an anti trans book, it's just a book that debunks neurosexist myths, studies, and publications). It's an excellent read if you are interested in how much evidence there really is for significant neurological differences between men and women

Trans people have one of the highest suicide rates of all groups in history. This is very obviously caused by their condition, which despite what some may say, is absolutely an abnormality. They are not treated as badly as people with similar suicide (attempt and successful) rates, especially given the overall positive coverage of their group in most cases. But to pretend for a second that this isn't a problem, but something that's supposed to happen, that they're just "born in the wrong body"? No.

But, alas, then there's the problem. A fair amount of people are spreading misinformation here in the comments, either citing or using talking points that originate from a poor understanding of this study: https://journals.plos.org/plosone/article?id=10.1371/journal.pone.0016885. First off, the study itself, in the fifth paragraph of the Introduction, states "[ . . .] these limitations [in the data collection] preclude solid and generalisable conclusions." (Such as concluding suicide rates after SRS are higher than before). In addition to that, here is an interview with one of the researchers who authored that study, Dr Cecilia Dhejne: https://www.transadvocate.com/fact-check-study-shows-transition-makes-trans-people-suicidal_n_15483.htm. She explains how the ways this study is used to justify transphobic positions are not supported by the study itself.

There is utility in these broad generalizations of differences between male and female brains. It does demonstrate that transgender brains match those of the internally perceived gender rather than the one that matches your outward appearance or genetics. But it is still worth noting that these are differences that only appear on broad surveys where small differences can be teased out from the noise. The difference WITHIN a gender is far more significant than the difference between genders and most brains have only a few of the differences cited. You could not look at an individual brain and say "that is a male/female brain". You could only look at a bunch of brains already classified for you and say "these structures are on average slightly different and the ones self-identifying as transgender match these averages better than those averages." On an individual basis, there is no "male" or "female" brain.

Taking a group of people and finding similarities in regional brain size does not prove that it is related to a given behavior.  That's working backwards.  The real scientific test would be to predict that behavior based on these differences going forward in a random population.  Suddenly, you have a much harder task.  Also, given that >99% of the time, genetic sex=perceived gender, we need to look at  what causes this statistically rock solid link to be broken in a minute percentage in the population.  For example, is it exposure to hormone like-pesticides or sensitivity of some people to those pesticide?  If you really want to think about this scientifically, you can't just go down the PC path.

Hmm. That's interesting. Quite a while ago I've seen a video that states somewhat the opposite of what you guys claimed about brain differences.
The argument goes something like this:
On average, male brains and female brains are different in the said parts. But that's on average. Even within cisgender people, the value range in each group is so large, that most people fall in an overlapping section. In fact, the average female brain looks like not-so-extreme male brain, and vice versa.
Furthermore, the same studies that found that trans people have brains more similar to their gender rather than assigned gender was done on trans woman post-HRT, which could suggest that hormones determine these differences, and not earlier development.
